jokes.joke: Mitch Hedberg: I read that a man got stabbed in Tiberias and his condition is serious. And I'm just thinking, why is it always the 'condition' that's serious? Can’t we at least give the stabber a run for his money and call it 'a dramatic flair'?

Mitch Hedberg: I hear Iran has satellite images showing the destruction of an airbase, which is impressive until you realize that the most advanced photo editing they have is a sunburned cousin holding a grudge against Israel.

**Sarah Silverman:** So, it turns out an American destroyer is chilling in Diego Garcia, probably waiting for strategic bombers while sipping a piña colada. If you think about it, that’s just like me at any family gathering; I’m not there to deal with the drama, I’m just praying the dessert table arrives before the chaos—because really, why risk a missile when you can risk your dignity over Aunt Edna’s fruitcake?

Jerry Seinfeld: What's with thousands of drones returning to their launch bases after a light show? I mean, is that really how we plan a party these days? "Hey everyone, we'll dazzle you with lights, then promptly return home like a bunch of well-behaved kids! No cake, no ice cream, just a bunch of drones signing ‘thanks for coming’ on the way out!"

Lewis Black: So let me get this straight—Iran destroys an Israeli airbase and the response is, "We're gonna attack them alone!" I mean, really? What are they gonna do? Show up at the door like a pizza delivery guy trying to pay for last week’s order with a half-eaten slice? "Sorry, we couldn't coordinate with the U.S. this time, but we figured out a way to put on our big boy pants and handle it ourselves!" What’s next, a group text to "just send in the F-35s!"? We’ve got nation-states negotiating war like they're planning a potluck dinner—“Are you bringing the missiles, or should I?” Who’s in charge here, a bunch of twelve-year-olds with squirt guns?

**Jerry Seinfeld:** So, the Israeli Energy Minister says they might take military action against… themselves? It's like being in a fight with your own reflection. “Oh yeah? What’s your game plan, buddy? Are we doing this or just staring at each other for the next hour?” I mean, imagine if that were applied to daily life. You look in the mirror and think, “You’re threatening my energy, pal! I’ve got a military response for that… well, after breakfast, maybe.”

Lewis Black: So there’s a meeting in Istanbul with the U.S., Iran, and all these regional countries, and instead of peace talks, it looks more like a game of hot potato where everyone’s holding onto their failures like they’re prized possessions! I mean, Trump’s got a giant armada in the Gulf – it’s like he’s trying to win a war with a cruise ship reunion tour, and Iran's over there thinking, ‘We can’t look defeated, but we definitely need some of those pesky sanctions lifted!’ Meanwhile, the Iranian people are sitting behind closed doors thinking, "Can someone please let us in on this game of diplomatic charades? We didn’t ask to be the collateral damage in a reality show nobody wants to watch!"

Eddie Izzard: So, Iranian Foreign Minister Araghchi claims that military deployments don’t scare them. I mean, that's like a cat saying it's not afraid of a vacuum cleaner—only the vacuum cleaner has a much louder personality and can actually turn on its own! And then you’ve got Khaled Mashal from Hamas offering a ceasefire for five, seven, even ten years! That's a guarantee? Sounds more like a warranty on an art piece—you know, you can return it if it just sits there gathering dust for too long! And what’s up with the merchants in the Tehran Grand Bazaar planning protests? Isn’t that just a way of saying, “Can we get a refund on the chaos? This model’s a lemon!” Meanwhile, in Israel, it sounds like Netanyahu thinks Ehud Barak is shameless. Shameless? American politics is still trying to find out what that even looks like! It's a world gone wonderfully weird, like a circus where the clowns only juggle issues that nobody wants to catch!

Lewis Black: So now we’re stopping American congress members at the Israeli border because they’re deemed too critical of Israel? I mean, what’s next? Are we going to start checking people’s social media accounts before they can fly? “Sorry ma’am, you tweeted a bad meme about hummus, so just turn around and head back to your heartland!” It’s like a bad parody of an absurd reality show where the prize is simply getting to enter a country without your social conscience checked at the door!

**Eddie Izzard:** So, Iran decides to reject America’s offer to coordinate a military response, which is like refusing a dinner invitation because you hate the idea of splitting the check—and all the while you're tossing grenades like they're confetti! It’s a diplomatic party where no one shows up, and the only thing everyone agrees on is that the food's going to be dangerously spicy. Honestly, I just want to know, who brings a missile to a potluck? Isn’t there a rule about that?

Eddie Izzard: So, Israel’s threatening to attack Iran alone, like some overly ambitious kid on a playground announcing they’ll build a sandcastle without any friends because they’ve just discovered that they can, while Iran’s over there monitoring the situation like a really paranoid cat watching a cucumber – "Oh sure, go ahead, build that castle, but don’t come crying to me when the waves start a full-scale war! Meanwhile, the U.S. is flying drones like they’re just trying to find the right taco stand in Azerbaijan. It’s all very strategic, or as strategic as designing a paper airplane to win a fighter jet battle!"

**Mitch Hedberg:** I heard Iran got some fresh satellite images showing the destruction of an Israeli airbase. You know, that’s like using Google Maps to find your lost sandwich. “Looks like it’s toast and, uh, it’s taken its last flight.” If only I could launch my sandwich into orbit—I’d call that a galactic meal plan.

**Jerry Seinfeld:** So, have you heard about the Israeli Energy Minister? He says Israel will take military action if they feel threatened, even if they have an agreement with Iran. I mean, isn’t that like signing a peace treaty and then insisting on keeping your finger on the nuclear button just because someone said “boo”? It’s like agreeing to share dessert but still being prepared to battle it out over the last bite of cake. Why do we do that? It's as if the moment we sit down to negotiate, we automatically go for the hidden weaponry under the table!

Lewis Black: So let me get this straight: Iran launches some satellites, finds out they've "completely destroyed" an Israeli airbase, and meanwhile, the U.S. is sending a military aircraft to Azerbaijan for some covert operations. Covert operations? What are we, secretly delivering pizza? And as if that's not enough, Israel’s Energy Minister is already gearing up to "take military action" if they even so much as hear a sneeze from Iran! Folks, this is like watching a bunch of kids playing with fireworks and wondering why they’re shouting, "Fire bad!" It’s a circus—only the clowns are running countries and the bigger joke is that we’re all just sitting here, popcorn in hand, pretending we’re not about to get out our umbrellas for the inevitable fallout!

Mitch Hedberg: I love how a fighter jet was scrambled for a Wizz Air plane. Just imagine all those poor passengers—like, “Free snacks? I’ll take a missile with that!” And the security checks afterward were thorough, like they didn’t want to miss a single piece of luggage. If I were a suitcase, I would be sweating more than a nervous diplomat at a peace conference.

Mitch Hedberg: I heard a Jewish woman got lightly injured by some stones in Judea and Samaria. That’s a rough day when your GPS says, “Take a left after the terrorists and avoid the flying rocks.” I mean, can we just agree that if your car's getting a stone-throwing upgrade, it’s time to switch from a Toyota to a shield?

**Eddie Izzard:** So, there’s this Haredi couple on a Wizz Air flight with a network name that translates to "terrorist," and you have to wonder, was this their idea of a practical joke or just a really bad naming convention like "JavaScript Error" or "Your Wi-Fi is as slow as my love life"? I mean, it’s akin to hiding in a tree for three weeks and then yelling, “Surprise!” as the fighter jets are scrambled – I guess they really took their in-flight entertainment to a whole new level. Meanwhile, in Iran, the head of the Judiciary is preparing for confrontation like it’s a boxing match with a referee who’s too busy checking his email – because who puts their trust in the enemy when you could just funkily prepare for a showdown with a side of nuclear negotiations as if they were bringing hors d'oeuvres? It’s like inviting your foes for tea while wearing a T-shirt that says, “Caution: May Contain Explosive Conversations.”

Jerry Seinfeld: Isn’t it fascinating how the Israeli government just decided to throw transparency into the real estate game like it’s a new feature on a video game? “Hey, remember when land deals were as secretive as grandma’s cookie recipe? Well, now you can buy land in Judea and Samaria like you’re ordering a pizza! And who knew that getting a permit there was more complicated than assembling IKEA furniture? 'Do I need this Allen wrench or is it optional?' We’re in the middle of a geopolitical conflict, and I can’t help but think, ‘What’s the deal with making land buying easier? It’s like they woke up one morning and said, ‘You know what? Let’s just skip to the fun part of real estate – all the fighting over the property lines!’’”

Lewis Black: So Israel's forging an agreement with Somaliland over three major points: moving Palestinians to Somalia, establishing a military base there, and signing the Abraham Accords. Did someone mix up the Middle East with a game of Risk?! I mean, what's next? Are they going to build a Starbucks in the Sahara? “Hey, can I get an Israeli latte on the rocks while you plan an airstrike?!” The level of absurdity here is staggering! It’s like watching a three-ring circus where the animals are negotiating peace treaties while juggling grenades! Who needs enemies when you have geopolitical strategies that make absolutely no sense?
